case_name: Civil Appeal No. 986 of 1964 & Civil Appeal No. 987 of 1964

facts.text: Two appeals by special leave preferred against the order of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revision Cases Nos. 52 and 53 of 1960 relating to sales tax assessments on the respondent for 1955-56 and 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave are preferred against the order of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revision Cases Nos. 52 and 53 of 1960 relating to sales tax assessments made on the respondent for the years 1955-56 and 1956-57 respectively.

facts.text: Respondent has head office at Court Road and branch office at Big Bazaar, both in Kozhikode.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has two offices, the head office is at Court Road and the branch office, at Big Bazaar. Both the offices are in Kozhikode.

facts.text: Branch office does wholesale business and head office does retail business and they maintain separate accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The branch office does wholesale business and the head office does retail business and they maintain separate accounts.

facts.text: Goods sent from branch office to head office entered in accounts as transfers.

anchor.surface_text: The goods sent from the branch office to the head office are entered in the accounts as transfers.

facts.text: Head office maintains accounts disclosing goods transferred by branch office and goods purchased locally.

anchor.surface_text: The head office maintains accounts disclosing the goods so transferred by the branch office and also the goods purchased by it locally.

facts.text: Branch office has transactions with other customers.

anchor.surface_text: The branch office has also transactions with other customers.

facts.text: On April 6, 1957, Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Kozhikode, assessed respondent on net turnover of Rs. 9,30,565-10-5 for 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: On April 6, 1957, the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Kozhikode, assessed the respondent on the net turnover of his business of Rs. 9,30,565-10-5 for the assessment years 1955-56.

facts.text: Surprise inspection of head office by Intelligence Officer, North Zone, Kozhikode, recovered some books of accounts and records.

anchor.surface_text: But later on, on a surprise inspection of the head office by the Intelligence Officer, North Zone, Kozhikode, some books of accounts and records were recovered.

facts.text: On October 27, 1958, Sales Tax Officer issued notice to respondent proposing best judgment determination of escaped turnover based on recovered books.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, 1958, on the basis of the said books and records, the Sales Tax Officer issued a notice to the respondent proposing to determine to the best of his judgment the turnover which had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Respondent agreed to assessment of head office turnover on basis of secret books recovered, but objected to fresh assessment of branch office.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent agreed to the Sales Tax Officer assessing the turnover of the head office on the basis of the aforesaid secret books recovered from the shop, but objected to a fresh assessment being made in respect of the branch office at Big Bazaar.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer rejected objection and reassessed turnover of both offices.

anchor.surface_text: That objection was rejected and the Sales Tax Officer reassessed the turnover of the business of the respondent in the following manner

facts.text: For head office 1955-56, transactions in secret books were 135 of turnover in regular accounts, added 135 to regular turnover.

anchor.surface_text: He found that in regard to the head office the transactions disclosed in the secret books were 135 of the turnover recorded in the regular accounts and on that basis added 135 to the turnover disclosed in the regular books of the said office.

facts.text: Same percentage applied to branch office, added 135 to its regular turnover.

anchor.surface_text: He then applied the same percentage in regard to the assessment of the turnover of the branch office. He added 135 to the turnover found in the regular accounts of the branch office.

facts.text: Total turnover assessed at Rs. 19,71,805-13-5, sales tax Rs. 16,269.37 for 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: He assessed the total turnover of the two offices at Rs. 19,71,805-13-5. On the basis of the said total turnover the respondent was assessed to sales tax amounting to Rs. 16,269.37.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal against the said order of the Sales Tax Officer to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner without any success.

facts.text: Appeal to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The further appeal preferred by him to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal was also dismissed.

facts.text: Revision to High Court in T.R.C. No. 52 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The said order was taken in revision to the High Court of Kerala in T.R.C. No. 52 of 1960.

facts.text: For 1956-57, Sales Tax Officer issued notice for best judgment based on secret accounts from head office inspection.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the secret accounts discovered in the surprise inspection of the head office, the Sales Tax Officer issued a notice to the respondent proposing to determine to the best of his judgment the turnover which had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Respondent had no objection to head office reassessment on secret accounts, objected to branch office.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had no objection for a reassessment being made in respect of the turnover of the head office on the basis of the secret accounts discovered, but objected to the reassessment of his branch office.

facts.text: For 1956-57 head office, escaped assessment general goods 200 of assessed turnover, sugar 500, added accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the head office he found in regard to the general goods that the escaped assessment was 200 of the turnover assessed and in regard to sugar, 500 of the assessed turnover. He, therefore, added 200 and 500 to the turnover of the general goods and the turnover of sugar respectively.

facts.text: Same percentages added to branch office turnover for general goods 200 and sugar 500 though no secret books discovered there.

anchor.surface_text: In the same manner in regard to the turnover of the branch office, though no secret books were discovered in respect of that office he added to the turnover already assessed 200 of the turnover of the general goods and 500 of the turnover of sugar.

facts.text: Total turnover for 1956-57: two offices Rs. 39,66,377-2-6 (head Rs. 2,21,251-14-5, branch Rs. 37,45,125-4-1).

anchor.surface_text: With the result he fixed the total turnover of the two offices at Rs. 39,66,377-2-6 made up of the turnover of the head office at Rs. 2,21,251-14-5 and of the branch office at Rs. 37,45,125-4-1.

facts.text: Respondent filed revision in High Court T.R.C. No. 53 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent pursued the matter up to the High Court. T.R.C. No. 53 of 1960 was the revision filed by him in the High Court.

facts.text: High Court set aside Tribunal orders for both years on ground that branch office escaped assessment finding was error of law based on conjecture.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the orders of the Sales Tax Tribunal in respect of both the assessment years on the ground that the finding of the escaped assessment so far as the branch office was concerned amounted to an error of law, because it was based on conjecture.

facts.text: High Court rejected State's plea for remand for fresh assessment, dismissed revisions.

anchor.surface_text: Rejecting the plea of the State that the matter should be remanded for a fresh assessment, the High Court dismissed the revisions.

facts.text: Secret accounts discovered only in head office, none in branch office.

anchor.surface_text: though no secret books were discovered in respect of that office

facts.text: State argued branch office must have maintained secret accounts corresponding to head office, suppression justified percentage application.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Govinda Menon, learned counsel for the State, argued that the High Court was wrong in holding that the best judgment assessment was capricious. He pressed on us to hold that the branch office must have maintained secret accounts corresponding to the secret accounts discovered in respect of the head office

facts.text: Respondent contended no basis for STO to hold separate secret accounts for branch, no material for best judgment, assessment capricious.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sreedharan Nambiar, appearing for the respondent, contended that there was no basis for the Sales Tax Officer to hold that the respondent maintained separate accounts in respect of the branch office business, that there was absolutely no material before the Sales Tax Officer to sustain his best judgment assessment

facts.text: Court found Sales Tax Officer acted capriciously and arbitrarily in assessing branch office by applying head office ratio without relevant material.

anchor.surface_text: From the discovery of secret accounts in the head office, it does not necessarily follow that a corresponding set of secret accounts were maintained in the branch office... the impugned assessments were arbitrarily made by applying a ratio between disclosed and concealed turnover in one shop to another shop of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals, no costs to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed. But, as regards costs, it is not a fit case for awarding costs to the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent was keeping secret accounts and had not disclosed entire dealings.

anchor.surface_text: It has been established that the respondent was keeping secret accounts and that he had not disclosed his entire dealings.
These two appeals by special leave are preferred against the order

At the outset the relevant provisions of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125 M.E.  XI of 1125 , may be noticed Section 12. -  1  Every dealer whose turnover is ten thousand Indian rupees or more in a year shall submit such return or returns relating to his turnover, in such manner, and within such periods as may be prescribed.  2   a  If the assessing authority is satisfied that any return submitted under sub-section  1  is correct and complete, he shall assess the dealer on the basis thereof. If no return is submitted by the dealer under sub-section  1  before the date prescribed or specified in that behalf or if the return submitted by him appears to the assessing authority to be incorrect or incomplete, the assessing authority shall assess the dealer to the best of his judgment Provided that before taking action under this clause the dealer shall be given a reasonable opportunity of proving the correctness and completeness of any return submitted by him.

concepts.interpretation: Assessing authority must not act dishonestly, vindictively or capriciously; must make fair estimate based on relevant material including local knowledge, previous returns; honest guess-work with reasonable nexus to available material and circumstances; not wild guess or capricious without regard to material.

concepts.unlisted_description: Best judgment assessment when return incorrect, incomplete or not submitted

concepts.interpretation: Jurisdiction of High Court confined only to whether Tribunal decided erroneously or failed to decide any question of law.

anchor.surface_text: The expression to the best of his judgment in the said clause is presumably borrowed from section 23 4  of the Income-tax Act.

What is the scope of section 12 2  b  of the Act ? The expression to the best of his judgment in the said clause is presumably borrowed from section 23 4  of the Income-tax Act. The said expression in the Income-tax Act was the subject of judicial scrutiny. The Privy Council in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Laxminarayan Badridas has considered those words. Therein it observed He  the assessing authority  must not act dishonestly, or vindictively or capriciously because he must exercise judgment in the matter. He must make what he honestly believes to be a fair estimate of the proper figure of assessment, and for this purpose he must, their Lordships think, be able to take into consideration local knowledge and repute in regard to the assessees circumstances, and his own knowledge of previous returns by and assessments of the assessee, and all other matters which he thinks will assist him in arriving at a fair and proper estimate and though there must necessarily be guess-work in the matter, it must be honest guess-work. In that sense, too, the assessment must be to some extent arbitrary.

concepts.interpretation: Limits implicit in 'best of his judgment': faculty to decide with wisdom truly and legally, not arbitrary caprice; element of guess-work but reasonable nexus to available material and circumstances; not capricious without regard to material.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: be able to take into companysideration local knowledge and repute in regard to the assessees circumstances, and his own knowledge of previous returns

concepts.unlisted_description: Standard for tax assessment where returns deficient: honest, fair estimate based on relevant material, not capricious or arbitrary

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the orders of the Sales Tax Tribunal in respect of both the assessment years on the ground that the finding of the escaped assessment so far as the branch office was concerned amounted to an error of law, because it was based on conjecture.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal deciding erroneously on question of law (capricious assessment) allows High Court interference; no interference with pure findings of fact.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: es, as in making the best judgment assessment the said authorities companysidered all the available materials and applied their mind and tried their b

concepts.unlisted_description: Distinction from question of fact for appellate/revision jurisdiction; capricious assessment is error of law

anchor.surface_text: As we will point out immediately, the Sales Tax Officer acted capriciously and arbitrarily in assessing the respondent, which he could not do under section 12 2  b  of the Act and the Tribunal confirmed that order.

arguments.claim: Under section 12(2)(b) best judgment assessment must not be dishonest, vindictive or capricious but honest guess-work with reasonable nexus to material

anchor.surface_text: What is the scope of section 12 2  b  of the Act ? The expression to the best of his judgment in the said clause is presumably borrowed from section 23 4  of the Income-tax Act. The said expression in the Income-tax Act was the subject of judicial scrutiny.

arguments.claim: the impugned assessments were arbitrarily made by applying a ratio between disclosed and concealed turnover in one shop to another shop of the assessee

anchor.surface_text: But in this case there was no material before the assessing authority relevant to the assessment and the impugned assessments were arbitrarily made by applying a ratio between disclosed and concealed turnover in one shop to another shop of the assessee.

arguments.claim: matter should not be remanded for fresh assessment as department had opportunities and persisted with impugned assessments

holdings.text: Under section 12(2)(b) of the Act, the power to assess to the best of judgment implies limits: judgment must be with wisdom, not arbitrary caprice; guess-work must have reasonable nexus to available material and circumstances, not capricious without regard to material.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 12 2 b of the Act, power is conferred on the assessing authority in the circumstances mentioned thereunder to assess the dealer to the best of his judgment. The limits of the power are implicit in the expression best of his judgment. Judgment is a faculty to decide matters with wisdom truly and legally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council interpretation of similar phrase in Income-tax Act, emphasizing honest fair estimate based on relevant material; confirmed by Calcutta and Patna High Courts.

holdings.text: The Sales Tax Officer acted capriciously and arbitrarily in assessing the branch office turnover by applying the percentage of suppression from head office secret accounts without any relevant material.

anchor.surface_text: As we will point out immediately, the Sales Tax Officer acted capriciously and arbitrarily in assessing the respondent, which he could not do under section 12 2 b of the Act and the Tribunal confirmed that order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No secret accounts found in branch; no necessary inference of corresponding suppression; no other material like customer accounts or circumstances considered.

holdings.text: The Tribunal decided erroneously on a question of law by upholding the capricious best judgment assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It is a clear case where the Tribunal decided erroneously on a question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Capricious assessment violates limits of s.12(2)(b); constitutes error of law attracting High Court jurisdiction under s.15B.

holdings.text: The impugned assessments did not satisfy the tests for valid best judgment assessment as there was no relevant material and they were arbitrarily made by applying head office ratio to branch office.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that in the instant case the impugned assessment satisfied the said tests ? From the discovery of secret accounts in the head office, it does not necessarily follow that a corresponding set of secret accounts were maintained in the branch office...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discovery in head office does not prove same rate of suppression in branch; no other evidence used; pure surmise.

holdings.text: The finding of escaped assessment for the branch office amounted to an error of law as it was based on conjecture.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the orders of the Sales Tax Tribunal in respect of both the assessment years on the ground that the finding of the escaped assessment so far as the branch office was concerned amounted to an error of law, because it was based on conjecture.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed with High Court; assessment lacked material, was capricious.

holdings.text: High Court jurisdiction under s.15B confined to whether Tribunal erred or failed on question of law; here it did err.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the jurisdiction of the High Court under section 15B is confined only to the question whether the Tribunal has either decided erroneously or failed to decide any question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.15B; applied to facts where error on law present.

holdings.text: The matter should not be remanded for fresh assessment as department had opportunities but persisted with arbitrary assessments.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural history shows department failed to use material at multiple levels; High Court discretion upheld.

holdings.text: High Court rightly set aside the Tribunal orders.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, rightly set aside the orders of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from above holdings on capriciousness and error of law.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Laxminarayan Badridas

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Laxminarayan Badridas

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Laxminarayan Badridas
precedents.cited_proposition: The expression 'to the best of his judgment' requires the assessing authority to make an honest fair estimate based on relevant material like local knowledge, previous returns, etc., involving honest guess-work, not dishonest, vindictive or capricious action
precedents.cited_holding: He must make what he honestly believes to be a fair estimate of the proper figure of assessment... it must be honest guess-work. In that sense, too, the assessment must be to some extent arbitrary.

precedents.citation: Jagadish Prosad Pannalal v. Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Jagadish Prosad Pannalal v. Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal, companyfirmed the assessment made by the sales tax authorities, as in making the best judgment assessment the said authorities companysidered all the available materials and applied their mind and tried their best to companye to a companyrect companyclusion.

precedents.case_name: Jagadish Prosad Pannalal v. Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Best judgment assessment under Sales Tax Act upheld where authorities considered all available materials, applied mind and arrived at correct conclusion

precedents.citation: Doma Sahu Kishun Lal Sao v. State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: Doma Sahu Kishun Lal Sao v. State of Bihar refused to interfere with the best judgment assessment of a Sales Tax Officer as he took every relevant material into companysideration, namely, the situation of the shop, the rush of the customers and the stock in the shop and also the estimate made by the Assistant Commissioners in the previous quarters.

precedents.case_name: Doma Sahu Kishun Lal Sao v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Best judgment assessment upheld where Sales Tax Officer considered relevant material such as shop situation, customer rush, stock and previous estimates

anchor.surface_text: Under section 12 2 b of the Act, power is conferred on the assessing authority in the circumstances mentioned thereunder to assess the dealer to the best of his judgment.
